docs.lead_paragraph: THE image is frozen in her mind. A 12-year-old girl who witnessed one of the planes hitting the World Trade Center still sees it as a vivid picture. She can remember the expressions on people's faces, the color of the sky and the sounds of people crying and screaming. The memory replays constantly. An 8-year-old boy who, before Sept. 11, had trouble sleeping in his own room because he feared robbers would come in, now also fears that planes will crash into his bedroom windows. Some nights, he imagines he hears them flying, frighteningly close, toward his house.

headline.main: On the Lookout For High Anxiety

docs.abstract: Article on reactions such as heightened anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder that therapists are looking for in children in Westchester County, NY, in aftermath of September 11 terrorist attacks; experts, noting children's resiliency in trauma, warn that emotional fallout may continue to unfold; drawings; photo (M)
